linkedin_essay.text:
The Ottoman Empire took a different approach to managing its multi-ethnic population, and the results were equally instructive.

The millet system divided Ottoman society into self-governing religious communities â€” the Muslim millet, the Greek Orthodox millet, the Armenian millet, the Jewish millet, and others. Each millet was governed by its own religious leaders according to its own laws in matters of personal status (marriage, divorce, inheritance, education). The communities coexisted within the same empire but lived largely separate lives.

For centuries, this system provided stability. The Ottoman Empire was one of the most successful multi-ethnic polities in history, controlling southeastern Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa for over 600 years. But the millet system contained the seeds of its own destruction: by keeping communities separate and allowing them to maintain distinct identities, it ensured that when the pressures of modernity arrived â€” nationalism, mass literacy, democratic ideas â€” each community had the cultural infrastructure to demand its own nation-state.
